title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Stocks dropped in turbulent trading alongside other assets as investors' risk appetite diminished and the Fed signaled an eventual shift away from its easy-money pandemic policies. The Dow fell as much as 587 points before paring its losses to less than 200 points, while other markets steadied as well.

Bitcoin, the volatile digital currency that briefly became a trillion-dollar market, plunged as its monthlong slide morphed into a frenzied selloff.

Shares of special-purpose acquisition companies and firms they have taken public are tumbling, punishing individual investors who piled into the once-hot sector.

---

Microsoft said it plans to largely retire its Internet Explorer browser, adding to the digital scrap heap a product once at the center of one of the tech industry's biggest battles.

---

Target, Lowe's and the owner of T.J. Maxx reported robust sales and a jump in store visits during the spring, as Covid-related restrictions eased.

---

Some of Discovery's biggest shareholders are getting a premium price for their stakes under the deal that combines the firm with AT&T's media business.

---

Ford plans to undercut several rival producers of electric pickup trucks on price when its battery-powered F-150 goes on sale next year.

---

ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, said CEO Zhang would step down from his role to focus on long-term strategy.
